Title.evidence: Intrathecal Oxytocin for Postoperative Recovery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: 98 participants undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty were randomised

Participants.evidence: 98 participants undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either intrathecal oxytocin (100 μg) or saline

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated whether intrathecal oxytocin accelerates recovery from pain and disability after major surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the modelled pain trajectory, assessed from the day of hospital discharge over 8 weeks.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 98 participants undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Ninety patients were analysed (oxytocin: n=44; saline: n=46) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome showed no significant difference in pain trajectory between groups (intercept: −0.1, 95% CI: −0.8 to 0.6, p=0.746; slope: 0.1, 95% CI: 0 to 0.2, p=0.057).

Harms.evidence: No drug-related adverse effects were reported.

Funding.evidence: The study was stopped early due to lack of funding.
